mainClaim: Restrictive single-family zoning creates housing shortages, increases inequality, and stifles economic growth
evidence: Research across 200+ U.S. metro areas shows cities with strict zoning have 3.2x higher housing costs and 50% lower economic mobility. Minneapolis upzoning eliminated single-family-only zones in 2018, resulting in 18% increase in new housing construction and first rent decreases in a decade. Berkeley study estimates U.S. GDP is 9.5% lower ($2 trillion annually) due to zoning restrictions preventing workers from moving to high-productivity cities.
supportingPoints: Exclusionary zoning perpetuates racial and economic segregation
Artificial scarcity transfers wealth from renters to existing homeowners
Environmental impact: sprawl increases car dependence and emissions
Shortage drives homelessness crisis - 580,000 homeless, 15M vacant homes
limitations: Rapid upzoning can cause displacement if not paired with tenant protections. Character preservation has some value. Infrastructure costs need planning. Political implementation extremely difficult due to homeowner opposition.
